title: Combined micro-osmotic pump infusion and intracerebroventricular injection to study FGF1 signaling pathways in the mouse brain
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Implant dual-port guide cannula
Prepare mouse for surgery
Timing: 10–15 min
Prepare 8-week-old C57BL/6J male mice.
Note: Animals are housed individually under specific pathogen-free conditions in a temperature controlled environment with either a 12 h: 12 h or 14 h:10 h light: dark cycle.
All animal procedures are performed according to the National Institutes of Health Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals and approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at the University of Washington.
Record body weight and calculate buprenorphine dosage.
Set induction chamber to 2% isoflurane.
Place mouse inside the induction chamber for a duration of 2–5 min.
Once anesthetized, with an electric shaver, remove hair from the incision area on top of the head.
Apply eye lubrication to keep eyes moist during the surgery.
Set surgical station isoflurane flow to 1%–2%.
Place mouse in stereotaxic apparatus by opening the mouth with non-sterile thick forceps moving the tongue out of the way, and placing the top teeth in the hole on the mouth plate. (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1580-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Implant dual-port guide cannula
(A) Stereotaxic apparatus and controller unit set-up for mouse to implant a guide cannula.
(B) Stereotaxic holder containing a multiport guide cannula. Scale bar 1 cm.
(C) Mouse skull with reference points bregma, lambda, bone screw placement, and red x denoting the cannula placement.
(D) Mouse fixed in ear bar with guide cannula implanted targeting the third ventricle. Created with BioRender.com[href=http://BioRender.com].
Pull the nose cone over the mouth.
Place the animal in the ear bars.
Tighten the nose cone and the ear bars to ensure the head is firmly in place.
Ensure the depth of anesthesia by performing a toe pinch. The mouse should not react.
Skin preparation
Timing: 2 min

Sterilize the shaved incision area with 3 alternating scrubs of betadine and alcohol wipes.
Begin sterilizing scrubs along what will be the incision line in a circular motion and extend outward.
Implant third ventricle cannula
Timing: 20 min
Replace gloves with sterile surgical gloves for surgery.
Using sterile forceps, place the guide cannula in the holder on the stereotaxic device to ensure the cannula tip is perpendicular, straight down by viewing it from multiple angles. (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Connect a 1 cm vinyl catheter to the osmotic pump port.
Seal the end of the catheter by melting the tube close with forceps just removed from the hot bead sterilizer.
Using dog-tooth forceps in one hand, grasp the skin between the eyes. On the other hand, use a scalpel to make a small incision along the midline in the center of the head.
Use cotton swabs to clean the skull and, by opening using lateral traction, the incision of the skin will stay open.
Use the guide cannula to level the skull.
Move the tip of the guide cannula to lambda (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C), touch the skull and zero all the coordinates on the controller by pressing reset.
Move the guide cannula to bregma and touch the skull. Look at the Z coordinate to determine if the distance is within 0.1 mm, indicating the skull is level.
Once level, touch the tip of the guide cannula at bregma and zero all the coordinates.
Move the guide cannula to the 3V coordinates -1.8 mm posterior to bregma and midline zero.
Mark the coordinate on the skull for the guide cannula (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Move the guide arm out of the way.

Drill three holes for the screws ensuring that the holes are from the sutures on the skull and screws will not block placement of the guide cannula (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
It is important to use light pressure to drill through the skull to ensure drill bit doesn’t subsequently damage the brain by going too deep.
Implant the screws, in one hand hold the curved forceps with a small bone screw. In the other hand, use the screwdriver to screw in the screws.
Critical: Ensure the head is secure in ear bars to prevent any movement of the head while placing the screws.
Once the screws are in place, move the cannula back into place, touch the skull and ensure the guide cannula lines up with the mark made.
Drill a hole for the guide cannula, then lower the guide cannula to -5 mm. The base of the cannula should be 0.3 mm off the skull surface.
Coordinates for dual-port cannula.
A/P: -1.8.
M/L: 0.
D/V: -5.00.
If bleeding occurs during guide cannula placement, use a sterile cotton tip applicator to apply light pressure until bleeding has stopped.
Critical: The cannula is implanted directly through the superior sagittal sinus and therefore bleeding is expected. Direct pressure with a sterile cotton-tipped applicator applied for 1–2 min, or sterile gauze pads wrapped around the cannula can be used to stop the bleed. Ensure that bleeding has completely stopped prior to cementing the cannula in place.
Cement cannula in place (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).
Mix the acrylic and Ortho-Jet powder in a 1:2 ratio in a small plastic cup. Remove the needle on a 3 mL twist top syringe, fill the syringe with the acrylic solution and twist on the capped needle.

Uncap the needle and squeeze the acrylic on the skull covering the 3 implanted screws fully and bottom ½ of the guide cannula.
Let acrylic dry completely (approximately 10–15 min).
Remove the cannula holder and ensure the cannula is not moving out of place. Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Place a long dummy cannula obturator in the guide cannula and screw into place.
Clean tools with alcohol wipes before placing into bead sterilizer if multiple animals are undergoing surgery.
Postoperative care
Timing: 5–10 min
Remove the mouse from the nose cone and place it on a heating pad.
When heart rate and breathing have increased sufficiently and before the animal is mobile, administer buprenorphine subcutaneously. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Return animal to clean cage on a heating pad. Make sure the animal has access to water or gel and food.
Allow the mouse to recover for a week before performing injections or implanting an osmotic pump.
Critical: Standard Allentown shoebox cages are used for housing mice after surgery. Monitor mice daily and replace dummy cannula if it is removed.
Osmotic pump priming and implanting
Timing: 1–2 days
Preparation of micro-osmotic pump – prime the osmotic pump the day before surgery.
Cut vinyl catheter tubing into 5 cm pieces using sterilized scissors.
In a biosafety cabinet, create a sterile field to prepare osmotic pumps. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Drop pump flow moderator and catheter into the sterile field.
Adjust the metal tube in the flow moderator so that 3 mm is visible above the white cap.
Connect the 3 cm catheter tubing to the flow moderator.
Fill one sterile 1 mL syringe with U0126 and a second 1 mL syringe with vehicle.
Connect the filling needle to the 1 mL syringe.

Insert the filling needle to the bottom of the pump. Slowly fill the pump while withdrawing the needle until a small bubble of liquid forms outside the pump.
Fill the catheter tubing-flow moderator from the catheter tubing end.
Insert the flow moderator into the osmotic pump.
Prime the osmotic pump in a sterile 15 mL falcon tube fully submersed in sterile saline solution at 37°C for 24 h. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A) Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].

Preparation for micro-osmotic pump implantation
Timing: 20 min
Sterilize surgical tools, gauze for surgery, icv tubing, and injectors. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Set up nose cone by connecting oxygen and isoflurane.
Turn on the bead sterilizer.
Create a sterile field.
Drop gauze, scalpel, and surgical supplies onto a sterile field.
Open sterilized tool kit and lay tools into the sterile field.
Prepare buprenorphine for postoperative care.
Prepare mouse
Timing: 7–10 min
Record body weight and calculate buprenorphine dosage.
Set induction chamber to 2% isoflurane.
Place mouse inside induction chamber.
Once anesthetized, remove hair from the incision area on the back between the scapulae with an electric shaver.

Apply eye lubrication to keep eyes moist during the surgery.
Set surgical station isoflurane flow to 1%–2%.
Place mouse in the nose cone.
Ensure the depth of anesthesia by performing a toe pinch. The mouse should not react.
Clean the shaved incision area with three alternating scrubs of betadine and alcohol wipes.
Begin along what will be the incision line in a circular motion and extend outward.
Drape mouse with a sterile sheet containing a small window for the surgical area.
Implant osmotic pump
Timing: 5–7 min
Use small scissors to make a small incision the diameter of the osmotic pump between the scapulae.
Create a pocket for the pump under the skin by gently inserting thick forceps into the incision the same length as the osmotic pump. Open and close the forceps to spread the subcutaneous tissue.
Insert a filled pump connected to vinyl catheter tubing into the pocket with the catheter and flow moderator facing the guide cannula. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
The pump should rest below the incision to one side of the spine.
Carefully remove the tubing connected to the infusion port on the guide cannula using forceps.
Cut the catheter tubing from the osmotic pump to fit the length (ca. 3 cm) and connect tubing to the guide cannula. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E).
Close incision
Timing: 2–5 min
Place 2–4 interrupted sutures, closing the skin around the catheter tubing. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F).
Inspect the incision site to ensure it is completely closed.
Administer icv injection
Administer icv injections
Timing: 10 min
Prepare icv injection Hamilton syringes for use, one for FGF1 and one for U0126.
Drop the sterile icv tubing and the injectors into sterile field.
Connect one end of icv tubing to the 10 ul Hamilton syringe and remove the plunger.

Fill a 3 mL syringe with sterile water and attach a 25 gauge needle.
Connect the syringe to the icv tubing and fill the icv tubing and Hamilton syringe with sterile water.
Replace the Hamilton syringe plunger.
Disconnect the syringe and connect the injector.
Pull 1 ul of air into the tube to separate the sterile water and the drug.
Place the injector into the drug and pull in 4–5 ul.
While mouse is under anesthesia place injector into the U0126 solution and pull out the plunger to fill the icv tubing.
Remove the long dummy cannula obturator from the guide cannula and insert the injector (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C) with the syringe filled with U0126.
Depress the plunger to administer U0126 (2 μL/min), remove the injector and replace the dummy cannula obturator.
Critical: Watch the air bubble move in the icv tubing to ensure fluid is flowing through the cannula during the icv injection. Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Wait 10 min and repeat steps 72 and 75 with the syringe filled with FGF1.
After the icv injections are complete replace with the short dummy cannula to create passage for flow through the osmotic pump.
Critical: The short dummy cannula ensures the osmotic pump flow is not obstructed.
Postoperative care
Timing: 5–10 min
Remove the animal from nose cone and place on a heating pad.
When heart rate and breathing have increased sufficiently and before the animal is mobile, administer buprenorphine subcutaneously. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Return animal to the cage on a heating pad. Make sure the animal has access to gel or water and food.
Western blot validation
Isolate hypothalamus for western blot
Timing: 10–15 min
Sacrifice the mouse 24 h post icv injection/osmotic pump implant.
Use CO2 to euthanize the animal.
Carefully dissect the brain from the skull.

Place the whole brain into an ice-cold metal mouse brain matrix. (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1580-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Hypothalamus isolation
(A) Mouse brain placed in metal brain matrix ventral side up. Arrow referencing the Circle of Willis. Scale bar 1 cm.
(B) One razor blade placed at the anterior and one at the posterior region of the Circle of Willis to generate a coronal section. Scale bar 1 cm.
(C) Coronal section place on flat metal surface on ice. Black circle representing the tissue punch of the medial basal hypothalamus. Scale bar 0.5 cm. Created with BioRender.com[href=http://BioRender.com].
Use two new razor blades to cut a 1.5 mm coronal section of the hypothalamus.
Use the Circle of Willis as a marker for the locations of the razor blades. (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Place the coronal section on a metal block on ice.
Punch out the mediobasal hypothalamus with a 3 mm tissue punch. (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Place the mediobasal hypothalamus into a labeled tube.
Place a hole in the top of the tube to release the pressure to avoid tube rupturing.
Drop tube to snap freeze in liquid nitrogen.
Samples can stay in liquid nitrogen until all samples are collected.
Store at −80°C until ready to process or process immediately.
Critical: Remove osmotic pump and measure the volume of remaining liquid to ensure adequate flow of drug occurred.
Pause point: Tissue can be stored at −80°C for up to 6 months.
Isolate protein from hypothalamus
Timing: 20–30 min
Place each sample on ice and pipet 200 μL of cold Lysis buffer.
Set sonicator to Duty cycle 50% and set power to 5.
Critical: Protect your ears by wearing noise-canceling earmuffs.
Sonicate the sample with three pulses five-second each to ensure the tissue has been fully homogenized.
Clean sonicator between samples with deionized water and Lysis buffer.

Centrifuge samples 10,000 × rcf for 15 min at 4°C.
Transfer supernatant, containing the proteins of interest, into a new tube on ice.
Store protein at −80°C.
Pause point: Protein can be stored at −80°C for up to 6 months.
Measure protein concentration by following the manufacturer’s protocol for BCA protein assay kit[href=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/MAN0011430_Pierce_BCA_Protein_Asy_UG.pdf].
Prepare protein samples and run gel
Timing: 10–25 min
Calculate total protein concentration to load on the gel for proper concentration for “linear range.”
Prepare samples to load 15 μL with 3 μg protein per well.
Add correct concentration of Protein Sample loading buffer.
Heat samples at 100°C for 5 min.
Running and transferring the gel
Timing: 2–2.5 h
Place 26 well 10% criterion gel in the Criterion cell buffer tank and fill the tank with BoltTM Running Buffer.
Critical: Remove the white tap strip across the bottom of the gel.
Load 5 ul of the Chameleon Duo Pre-Stained Ladder into the first well.
Pipet 15 ul of each sample into the gel to avoid pipetting bubbles into the well.
Connect the Criterion cell to PowerPac and run electrophoresis at 200 V for 25 min.
While the gel is running, prepare for the transfer.
Submerge the PVDF membrane cut the exact size of the gel in methanol to saturate it completely.
Soak blotting papers and sponge pads in cold transfer buffer.
Carefully remove the gel from the plastic casing.
Assemble the Bio-rad submerged electrophoretic protein transfer apparatus containing both the gel and the PVDF membrane according to bio-rad Instructions[href=https://www.bio-rad.com/webroot/web/pdf/lsr/literature/4006190b.pdf].
Place ice pack inside the transfer chamber.
Run the transfer chamber at 100V for 45–60 min in a cold room.
Critical: Ensure all the running and transfer apparatus are clean.
Incubate and image membrane
Timing: 1 day
Remove membrane from transfer apparatus.

Follow the Total Protein Stain manufacture protocol[href=https://www.licor.com/documents/1q6nvqiov23om7n80hxo046w9mpfqx3s].
Rinse the membrane in ultra-pure water.
Incubate in 5 mL of REVERT Total Protein Stain solution for 5 min with gentle rocking.
Decant Total Protein Stain Solution completely.
Rinse membrane 2 × 30 s with 5 mL of Wash Solution. Briefly rinse membrane in water.
Image membrane immediately in 700 nm channel with Odyssey FC according to the manufacture protocol. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Incubate the membrane in 5 mL of REVERT Reversal solution for 5–10 min with gentle shaking. Do not reverse for longer than 10 min.
Rinse membrane briefly with water and proceed to block.
Block membrane in blocking Intercept Blocking Buffer for 1 h at room temperature 68 degree F (RT).
Wash membrane 1 × 15 min, 2 × 5 min at RT, replacing the wash buffer each time.
Incubate blot in pERK 1:1,000 and total ERK 1:2,000 overnight 12–14 h in cold room gentle shaking.
Rinse membrane with wash buffer 1 × 15 min, 2 × 5 min at RT, replacing the wash buffer each time.
Incubate blot with secondary antibody IRDye 800CW 1: 15,000 and IRDye 680RD 1:15,000 in wash buffer + 0.01% SDS for 1 h at RT gently rocking.
Wash membrane with wash buffer 1 × 15 min, 2 × 5 min at RT with wash buffer, and rinse membrane with wash buffer.
Detect using Odyssey FC for 700 and 800 channels for 2 min. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Note: Refer to manufacture protocol and online resources[href=https://www.licor.com/bio/webinars/image-studio-4.0-for-odyssey-fc-image-acquisition].
Critical: The Odyssey FC is sensitive to contamination, leading to excess fluorescence on the membrane during detection. To avoid nonspecific fluorescence, ensure incubation boxes and trays used for the western blot are clean before use.
